comments:
BIOL102 is Introduction to Biology B. It covers the structure and function of animals, their evolution and development, and their relationship to other animals in the environment. BIOL102 is the companion course to BIOL101, but they can be taken in either order. This course fulfills the College Sector V: Living World.

Students had mixed opinion about this course. Some students thought the course material was intriguing. Many students complained that the course had too much “rote memorization and no critical thinking.” 

Students appreciated Professor Dunham’s helpful slides. Some students also praised Professor Dunham for his humor while other students thought that Professor Dunham was somewhat boring.

Most students who take BIOL102 are biology majors or premedical students. Students believed the class was challenging, with a tough curve. Professor Dunham’s exams were based of his slides, thus studying for exams proved to be rather easy.

This course covers the following topics; spherical astronomy, timekeeping and coordinate systems, astrostatistics, telescopes, CCD's, signal processing. Two one-hour daytime lectures each week plus three-hour evening lab in smaller groups. Attendance at one lab session per week is required by each student - multiple times are scheduled due to the uncertainty and unpredictability of weather conditions for observing. This course requires substantial out-of-class time dedication and commitment to sharing work in small groups. 

Students found this course to be interesting and enjoyable, but "stressful" due to lack of organization. Many students wanted strict, early deadlines to motivate them, and wanted more guidance along the way, especially for using the software required for the end-of-semester projects.

Students claimed that Professor Aguirre was helpful, but wished he could give more "unsolicited guidance" and felt that his attention was a bit divided since this class is shared with ASTR150.

This course is intended for science majors. Prerequisites include ASTR 001, or ASTR 007, or ASTR 011, or ASTR 012. If a student has only taken ASTR 001, MATH 240-241 will also be required. This review is based on the four submitted student comments.
